title: Merch as Slang: What It Means & How to Use It on TikTok

steps.title: In slang, the word merch means to prove something.
steps.content: In slang, the word merch means to prove something. While most people know “merch” as an abbreviation for merchandise, it is often used differently in Chicago and/or by Gen Z. This meaning of the word originated in Chicago, Illinois, and is said when you want proof of something. [1] X Research source For example, if someone tells you a mutual friend has been talking behind your back, you might say “merch” instead of saying “prove it.”

steps.title: Say merch to prove or get proof of something.
steps.content: Say merch to prove or get proof of something. If someone says something and you suspect they’re lying or exaggerating, say “Merch” as a way of asking them to prove it. Alternatively, if you’re the one who needs to prove what you’re saying, “merch” is another way of saying something like “I swear,” “ No cap ,” or “I have proof.” Here are some examples: [2] X Research source “I’m telling the truth. I’ll merch it on my mama.” “You’re actually going to ask your crush out? Merch!” “I just found $100 on the ground, and I can merch it.”

steps.title: Merch originated as a slang term in Chicago, Illinois.
steps.content: Merch originated as a slang term in Chicago, Illinois. Like many slang terms and phrases, the exact origin of merch being used this way is hard to pinpoint. However, it has historically been used almost exclusively in Chicago, leaving many non-Chicagoans confused when they hear the word in this context. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Gen Z has adopted the term online.
steps.content: Gen Z has adopted the term online. Over recent years, young people have begun using merch in this context even if they’re not originally from Chicago. This is likely because of the rise of slang on sites like TikTok , where users can watch videos from creators all over the world.

steps.title: Merch is short for merchandise.
steps.content: Merch is short for merchandise. While merch is an abbreviation for any type of merchandise, it is often used when referring to items sold in relation to a fandom, like a band, sports team, TV show, or movie. Popular merch items include things like T-shirts and accessories. [4] X Research source For example, if you bought a T-shirt advertising your favorite singer’s new album, you bought merch.

steps.title: Merching sometimes refers to posting promotions on social media.
steps.content: Merching sometimes refers to posting promotions on social media. When influencers or celebrities get paid to post products or ads on their platforms, like Instagram, some might say they’re merching. This likely comes from the word’s associations with merchandise and merchants. [5] X Research source For example, you might say “Do you follow the Kardashians on Instagram? They’re always merching.”

steps.title: Flodgin’
steps.content: Flodgin’ Flodgin’ is another slang word that’s pretty exclusive to Chicago, and it means lying. Someone might say “Stop flodgin’” when they know you aren’t telling the truth or when you’re pretending to be someone or something you aren’t. [6] X Research source For example, “Stop flodgin’. I literally saw you take money out of my purse.” The word “flodgin’” may have come from “camouflaging,” meaning to hide or conceal something.

steps.title: Fin
steps.content: Fin A “fin” is a five-dollar bill. This slang term may be used in other parts of the United States and Canada, but it is most commonly used in Chicago. If someone asks you for a fin, they’re asking you to give them five dollars. [7] X Research source For example, “Can you spot me a fin so I can get a snack?”

steps.title: Dibs
steps.content: Dibs Calling dibs means to claim something ahead of time, but in Chicago, the term often has a very specific meaning. Chicagoans often call dibs to claim their parking spots in winter, and they do so by placing random belongings, like patio furniture or suitcases, in the parking lot. [8] X Research source For example, if you just shoveled a bunch of snow out of your parking spot and you don’t want someone to take it after all your hard work, put a lawn chair in the spot as your dibs.

steps.title: Kickback
steps.content: Kickback In Chicago, house parties are often called kickbacks. Kickbacks differ from regular parties because they’re more chill and laid back while regular parties may be more lively and rowdy. Kickbacks are for friends to hang out together and relax. [9] X Research source For example, “Hey, we’re having a kickback at my house tomorrow night if you want to come.”

steps.title: Wear the jacket
steps.content: Wear the jacket In Chicago, “wearing the jacket” isn’t always literal. Dating back to the city’s gangster days, the phrase “wear the jacket” often means taking the blame for something or taking the fall for a crime. [10] X Research source This phrase comes from the cardboard or paper covering of a criminal case, known as the jacket. When someone was prosecuted, they “wore the jacket.” For example, you might say, “I knew he’d get in serious trouble if he got caught, so I wore the jacket instead.”
